There have been some bold promises made in the history of religions. The boldest I know of is the one Avalokiteshvara made, it goes way beyond the one made by Jesus (which is also pretty bold) and borders on the insane. Yet, as a buddhist, I find Avalokiteshvara's promise easier to understand and actually believe in. 
 
 Avalokiteshvara's promise is that anyone who says his name once will be taken by him at the time of death and brought to "the Holy Paradise in The West" from which the path to nirvana is straight and one way. 
 
 Now, he never said anything about believing in him (or if he's a she, the sex is a little ambigous), just say the name once and you're in the clear. That means that you can say the name now, once, and then forget about it, pray to Jesus or whomever you like, ask for forgiveness that you for one split second prayed to another God, curse that other God the rest of your life... and if, when you die, the promise made to you by Jesus fails for some reason and if the one made by Avalokiteshvara still stands you're safe anyway. 
 
 Avalokiteshvara doesn't mind that you hated him the rest of your life, that you prayed to another all that time, he's above that. You said the name once so you're on the list. Pretty long list by now, but you'll be on it. In fact, it's often described this way in its own tradition "Pray to everyone else first and if they come to help you then that's good. If they don't, call on me and I'll come!". To me that sounds more like a higher being talking to us than the idea of God demanding that we believe in Him. 
 
 I'm not saying this to be stupid or make fun of it, on a deeper level I can accept this idea. If I explained it you'd think it was really silly so maybe I shouldn't, but let's just say that if you accept a worldview where the individual person does not really exist in the ultimate sense, things like these are easier to accept.

 Lennart Möller specializes in the health hazards of air pollutants and the DNA damage that they cause. Since 2001 he is a professor of environmental medicine at the department of bioscience at Karolinska Institutet, one of Europe's largest medical universities and Sweden's main centre for medical training and research. Beside his academic duties, Möller is an active member of Evangeliska Fosterlands-Stiftelsen, founded in 1856, a missionary organization within the Church of Sweden. He has edited and authored books on ethics and Gospels exegesis, and recently a volume on Biblical archaeology, The Exodus Case (2000).
 
 This book is the fruit of extensive travels in the Near East and Egypt. Its stated main purpose is to test a hypothesis: that the biblical texts of Genesis 11:27 through Exodus 40:38 are historically correct (pp. 14, 16). A secondary purpose (p. 13) is to evaluate and expand upon the works of the late Ron Wyatt (1933-1999). The work is presented with an explicitly scientific ambition. Möller wishes to subject his hypothesis to an unprejudiced test and encourages the reader to be critical but keep an open mind.
 
 So far, so good, it may appear. But there are disturbing signs already in the book's introduction. First, it is naïve to judge these long texts, preserved through thousands of years of oral and textual tradition, as either true or false in their entirety. Academic historians evaluate discrete factual statements, not entire books at one go. But Möller emphasizes that he is neither a theologian, a historian nor an archaeologist. In fact, he underlines that he does not know what these disciplines believe regarding the questions he takes on. Möller feels that he can thereby offer a fresh perspective.
 
 Then there are the references to Ron Wyatt. If ever there was a true native of Däniken Land, it was him. Wyatt's writings on Biblical archaeology are such extreme flights of fancy that even many creationist debaters dismiss them as wild imaginings.
